Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Fundamental Limits of Charge Transport in Organic Semiconductors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to develop large-area, low-cost organic field-effect transistors and organic photovoltaics with unprecedented performance and reproducibility. This goal will be achieved by using single-crystals to design and implement novel materials and device architectures. Results obtained on charge injection and transport will enable engineering of these high performance devices by spray-deposition.
The intellectual merit inheres in (1) exploring the intrinsic properties of soluble small-molecule organic semiconductors in single-crystal form, (2) incorporating successful candidates in spray-deposited devices, and (3) optimizing their performance by controlling film uniformity and device structure. Nondestructive contact deposition techniques will be used with high mobility semiconductors and with dielectrics promoting reduced operating voltages. Exploring the interplay between processing details and the resulting contact effects, film microstructure and charge transport will provide feedback for developing better devices. The project is transformational in devising a unique platform to answer questions about charge transport in technologically relevant materials, being the first to use single crystals of materials compatible with solution-deposition techniques.
The broader impacts are aligned with the anticipated importance of organic electronics to our economic progress; project results will advance high-performance devices that spark a new technology. In addition, graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students will gain knowledge and skill sets spanning crystal growth, device design, fabrication and characterization. Infrastructure and results will be integrated in a new course and outreach programs at the local science museum. The PI will persuade girls that science careers are exciting and possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of organic electronic devices has attracted attention over the past decades in light of their promising impact on contemporary applications.

Intellectual merit: This project had the goal to evaluate the fundamental performance limits of organic semiconductors and to incorporate them large-area electronics. It resulted in 2 book chapters and 21 manuscripts; the most important outcomes are summarized below.

(1) A simple and reliable strategy for reducing contact resistance in organic field-effect transistors (OFETs) was developed. This led to contact resistances of 200 Ωcm and charge carrier mobilities of 20 cm2/Vs. The method is based on creating high work function domains at the surface of the injecting electrodes to promote channels of enhanced injection. In addition to allowing the demonstration of high-mobility transistors with near ideal current-voltage characteristics, the use of this method has lead to accurate measurement of the charge carrier mobility, a critical step in a rational material design.

(2) It was discovered that the strain induced in the organic semiconductor layer due to the mismatch in the coefficients thermal expansion (CTE) of the consecutive layers creates electronic traps and can result in a crossover from a band-like to an activated transport. The CTE mismatch, a widely overlooked parameter in spite of its ubiquitous presence in layered devices, may be the key missing link to help achieve consistently high performance in organic semiconductors.

(3) The trap densities at semiconductor/dielectric interfaces was quantified using transistor measurements. It was found that density of trap states (DOS) depends on the nature and quality of the dielectric layer, as well as the composition of the organic semiconductor layer. Using DOS analysis, it was shown that isomers create trapping states, lowering device performance and stability.

(4) Polymorphism was tuned in thin-films and single crystals of several organic semiconductors to improve molecular packing and device performance. The polymorphism was controlled by the crystallization temperature, solvent used for processing and/or method chosen for deposition. From a device perspective, the formation of stable polymorphs is advantageous for the uniformity, reproducibility, and stability of devices.

(5) OFETs were fabricated on large-area flexible substrates by using a wide arsenal of processing methods and working with both known and novel organic semiconductors.

 

Broader impacts: This CAREER award was the catalyst that allowed the PI to shape a long-term vision for her career as researcher, educator, mentor, and advocate for diversity. The PI has embraced the teacher-scholar model and her actions are a proof of that. During the duration of this award, she dedicated significant effort in mentoring students and postdoctoral researchers and in helping them acquire the knowledge and the skills they need in order to be successful. In total, 18 students were trained under this grant (4 graduate students, 12 undergraduates and 2 high-school students). The PI engaged in extensive efforts to attract women to science and has established a strong tradition of mentoring female students (7 under this grant). Her students won prestigious awards: LeRoy Apker Award, Cambridge Gates, Churchill fellowship, Goldwater scholarship, NSF fellowships, and MRS graduate student gold award. In total, 9 undergraduates defended their honors theses working on this project and 7 co-authored manuscripts. Many of these undergraduates have continued their education by joining excellent graduate programs. Several students travelled to national labs to perform experiments (Oak Ridge and NIST). PI’s excellence in mentoring both in the classroom and the research lab was recognized by several university and departmental awards. The PI participated in numerous outreach activities, for example, she gave lab tours to groups of high school students through the Wake STEM program, and performed demos for children at the local children’s’ museum. She also organized several conferences, including MRS and SPIE.

 

Summary

This project contributed to the success of the organic electronics field by (1) improving the fundamental understanding on charge transport in the bulk of organic semiconductors and at the interfaces with contacts and dielectrics, (2) providing accurate conclusions about the potential and limitations of organic semiconductors as electronic materials, (3) designing and implementing device architectures that promote high performance; and (4) controlling thin-film order over a wide range of length scales to fabricate high performance, large-area organic devices on flexible substrates.  This interdisciplinary research program integrated education by creating a stimulating environment for training graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, including non-traditional and underrepresented minority students. Activities were carefully planned to teach them responsive research conduct, shape their ability to present results, and cultivate their community engagement. Several students visited the National Institute of Standards and Technology and at Oak Ridge National Laboratory to perform short projects. The PI was actively involved in enhancing understanding and excitement about the field of organic electronics by writing books, organizing conferences, participating in activities at local science museum, and offering research opportunities to students from local community colleges and high schools.
